title: Scam Detection Assessment - 10 Questions

items.text: You receive an email saying you've won $10,000 but need to pay $500 in processing fees first.
items.explanation: Real winnings never require upfront fees. This is a classic advance fee scam.

items.text: Your bank sends you an official letter asking you to update your account information online.
items.explanation: Banks do send legitimate account update requests, though always verify by calling them directly.

items.text: Someone on a dating app wants to move your conversation to WhatsApp immediately.
items.explanation: Moving off-platform quickly is a red flag - scammers want to avoid platform safety measures.

items.text: You get a call from 'Microsoft' saying your computer has been hacked and they need remote access.
items.explanation: Microsoft doesn't make unsolicited calls. This is a tech support scam.

items.text: A friend texts you asking to borrow money because they lost their wallet.
items.explanation: This could be legitimate, though always verify by calling them on a known number.

items.text: You're offered a job that pays $200/hour for data entry work from home with no experience required.
items.explanation: Unrealistic pay for simple work is a major red flag. These are often money laundering schemes.

items.text: Your credit card company sends you a new card before your old one expires.
items.explanation: Credit card companies routinely send replacement cards before expiration dates.

items.text: Someone claims they're stranded abroad and need you to wire money for emergency travel.
items.explanation: Emergency money requests, especially wire transfers, are classic scam tactics.

items.text: You receive a package you didn't order and there's no charge on your credit card.
items.explanation: While suspicious, this could be a legitimate mistake or gift. Monitor your accounts.

items.text: An investment advisor guarantees 50% returns with 'zero risk' on cryptocurrency.
items.explanation: No legitimate investment guarantees high returns with zero risk. This is an investment scam.

tips: Verify unexpected requests by contacting the person/organization through a known, trusted method
Be suspicious of urgent requests for money, personal information, or immediate action
Research investment opportunities independently and never trust 'guaranteed' high returns
